Issues.Title: String.Compare() Can not work in .Net 6
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 6.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

.NET Core 3.1

### Issue description

Source code example:
[StrCompare.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/8356647/StrCompare.zip)


### Steps to reproduce

Source code example
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "String.Compare() Can not work in .Net 6" (#6908)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[main] Update dependencies from dotnet/runtime" (#6895)

Issues.Title: Screenreaders don't announce window title when application opens.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

6.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

I haven't checked .net core, but it did the same in .net 5.0.

### Issue description

When an application loads, the form is in focus, but the active screen reader doesn't announce it's title when it should.
I have tried several workarounds, non of them make sense and actually should be done because this should work without any workarounds, but it didn't fix the issue. I have used nvda and windows10 narrator screen readers.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a standard windows forms app using the template without changing it.
2. Get a screen reader ([nvda](https://nvaccess.org) or windows10/11 narrator (ctrl+windows+enter) should do), launch it.
3. Build and launch.
4. The window opens and is in focus, but the screen reader doesn't announce it's title (the Form.Text property) when it pops up, but it should. To read the window title, you should alt+tab out then back again, as window title checking commands (Insert/capslock+t for nvda and capslock+t for narrator report wrong information).
I've made sure that the issue is reproducible not only on my pc, but on others as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Screenreaders don't announce window title when application opens." (#6896)

Issues.Title: Fixing TextBox accessible object leaks
Issues.Body:
Fixes #6885

## Proposed changes
- Use the `UiaDisconnectProvider` method cascade through the hierarchy of the classes to free objects held by accessibility tool
- Nullify needed objects

## Customer Impact
- TextBox memory will stop leaking

## Regression? 
- No

## Risk
- Minimal

## Screenshots

### Before
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159485312-4729b9b1-19bd-425c-ace0-f44b484beb53.png)

### After
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159485380-9b3d1f61-0460-40ea-b2a6-e3eff3695745.png)

### Future
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159487064-78e2893a-ad41-4f2b-92d5-c1f4951b3dfa.png)

This fix isn't clearing all possible memory leaks. In the future nulling the `Owner` property at the `ControlAccessibleObject` class could be added:
1. This method should be added to the ControlAccessibleObject class:
```
                internal void ClearOwnerControl()
                {
                    this.Owner = null;
                }
```
2. Owner property shoud be changed from this
`public Control Owner { get; }`
to something like this
`public Control? Owner { get; private set; }`
3. Calling of the `ClearOwnerControl` should be added/uncommented at the `ClearObjects` method of the `TextBoxBaseAccessibleObject` class
4. These changes will produce different sorts of warnings: non-nullable member will became nullable, additinal checks for null should be added, etc. We discussed it with @vladimir-krestov and decided, that it's better to fix this leak after Vladimir will add new `TextPattern` functionality to the Core branch.

## Test methodology
- Manual testing (_using WinDbg, see the screenshots above_)
- CTI team

## Test environment(s)
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19043.1586]
- .NET 7.0.0-preview.3.22159.12

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/6886)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Fixing TextBox accessible object leaks" (#6886)

Issues.Title: TextBox accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

`TextBox` accessible objects are left in memory after the `TextBox` control instance was inspected with accessibility tool (like `Accessibility Insights` or `Inspect`) and the form with `TextBox` is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened.

Report from WinDbg:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/159481920-cf26ae86-0a41-4d7c-a26f-5cb9d91de3e1.png)

**Expected behavior:**
Amount of the leaked objects should be minimized to the uncleanable static objects only.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the `TextBox` control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Press the second button to open the child form with `TextBox`.
3. Start the `Accessibility Insights` tools.
4. Run automated checks for the `TextBox` control using AI.
5. Close the child form.
6. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
7. DON'T close the AI tool.
8. Look for `TextBox` accessible objects left in memory (using `WinDbg`, or `dotMemory`, or another suitable tool).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TextBox accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#6885)
